content.title: Concept Title
content.definition: Precise definition of the economic concept (50-200 words).
key_points: Most important aspect of the concept
Second critical point about behavior or application
Third key point about implications or limitations
Fourth point about measurement or empirical reality
Fifth point about policy or practical relevance
Sixth point about historical development or current understanding
Seventh point about relationship to other concepts

examples.title: Real-World Example 1 Title
examples.description: Detailed description of example with specific data and context
examples.context: Why this example matters and what it illustrates

examples.title: Historical Example Title
examples.description: Important historical case demonstrating the concept
examples.context: Lessons learned and relevance to theory

examples.title: Comparative Example Title
examples.context: What the differences reveal about the concept

content.statement: One-sentence summary capturing the essence of the concept

explanation.intuition: Intuitive understanding that makes the concept accessible without jargon (100-150 words). Use analogies and everyday examples.
explanation.key_insight: The core insight that makes everything 'click' - the breakthrough understanding (100-150 words). Explain the mechanism or fundamental principle.
explanation.technical_details: Rigorous economic explanation with precise terminology (200-400 words). Include conditions, assumptions, and scope.
explanation.measurement: How this concept is measured in practice, including data sources and methodological challenges
explanation.historical_context: Development of the concept, key contributors, evolution of understanding
explanation.policy_implications: Relevance for economic policy, government intervention, or market regulation
explanation.limitations: Boundaries of the concept, where it doesn't apply, common misconceptions

sources.source: Mankiw, N.G. (2021). Principles of Economics, 9th ed. Cengage Learning.
Author, A. (YEAR). Journal Article Title. Journal Name, Volume(Issue), pages.
Official Agency. (YEAR). Official Statistics or Methodology. Publisher.
sources.relevance: Official measurement methodology or data source

sources.source: Advanced Textbook Author. (YEAR). Advanced Treatment. Publisher.

provenance.verification_notes: Content verified against sources listed above. Mathematical formulations validated. Examples cross-checked with empirical data.
